awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving Energy Reliability by Co-Optimization Planning for Interdependent Electricity and Natural Gas Infrastructure Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The electricity grid and the natural gas network are two essential infrastructure systems in the U.S. energy industry.  They are designed and managed independently. However, because of the planned retirement of many coal-fired generators, the deeper penetration of renewable energy sources, and the commercially sustainable gas price, their interactions have intensified over the last five years.  Hence, in order to ensure environmentally friendly, reliable, and cost-effective electricity and gas production and delivery, it is important to jointly optimize these two systems.  However, due to their scales, complexities, and requirements/regulations, such a co-optimization planning problem is very challenging in both modeling and computation aspects.  To address this critical challenge, this project will build analytical decision support models and design efficient solution methods to aid the energy industry in formulating and computing practical-scale co-optimization problems.  The effectiveness and benefit of co-optimization planning will be demonstrated and evaluated through an actual microgrid project and industrial collaborations.  In addition to including doctoral students in research and creating educational materials for the next generation energy system planners and operations researchers, concrete projects will be designed to involve  underrepresented students on utilizing analytical/computational tools to address real energy problems. 
 
Previous research on co-optimization planning of electricity and gas systems is limited, while also often neglecting critical reliability considerations, key random/uncertain factors, or the long-term multi-stage nature of planning problems.  This research project will address these shortcomings by (1) investigating key interactions between electricity and gas systems with different spatial-temporal granularities as well as multiple planning and operation levels;  (2) building a set of co-optimization planning models that simultaneously consider the multi-stage planning horizon, the hourly chronological operation details with critical random/uncertain factors, and the requirements of long-term reliability and short-term flexibility;  (3) designing and implementing high-performance computational methods and tools through advanced decomposition strategies, strong approximation approaches, and effective hybrid methods;  and (4) validating, demonstrating, and promoting the developed models and computational tools through an on-going microgrid project and established industry connections.

por.por_cntn:
The reliability of energy systems is crucial to ensuring that homes, businesses, and industries have access to the power they need to operate efficiently. As renewable energy sources are increasingly integrated into existing power grids, the randomness and intermittency associated with these sources pose a significant challenge to maintaining reliability in these systems. This project has focused on developing optimization tools to support decision-making for interdependent electricity and natural gas infrastructure systems, with the aim of improving their reliability.

One of the key results of this research is a set of strong decomposition algorithms that can compute robust optimization with decision-dependent uncertainty sets. These algorithms generalize and extend existing methods such as Benders decomposition and the basic Column-and-Constraint Generation (CCG) algorithms. In particular, the newly developed parametric CCG method has superior computational capacity and can handle various planning and operational problems. Note that robust optimization techniques have become very popular in energy and other critical infrastructural systems, as they can help decision-makers account for the uncertainty associated with major random factors and make more informed decisions with high reliability.

In addition to developing optimization tools, this project has studied a range of decision-making problems and developed fast computational methods for electricity and gas systems. Among them, one is a robust unit commitment (UC) model with decision-dependent demand response (DR), where DR can modify loads to align electricity and cheap energy generation. Another is a robust UC model for gas-fired generators with both left-hand-side and right-hand-side uncertainties. This project has also investigated several stochastic and chance-constrained optimal planning models for system expansion, along with a study on the duality of a conic AC power flow formulation in radial networks.

The research results and developed optimization tools have been disseminated through academic conferences, seminars, and publications in mainstream journals. They have also been used to teach stochastic and robust optimization methodologies in multiple Operations Research (OR) courses. Students have given positive feedback and have been motivated to apply these techniques to address decision-making problems in other complex and practical systems, such as healthcare and logistics systems. Given the popularity of robust optimization and the fundamental contributions of the developed optimization tools, the materials generated from this project will continue to be used to train the next generation of researchers and practitioners in the fields of OR and energy systems.

One of the doctoral students, who was heavily involved in this project and trained with this grant's INTERN Supplement, has successfully joined a DOE national lab. It is anticipated that this graduate will apply classical optimization techniques and new ones developed from this project to help the national lab address practical and sophisticated challenges in energy systems.
